Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Developing and Assessing Effective Cyberlearning within the STEMWiki Hyperlibrary

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a collaborative project involving the University of California, Davis (Award DUE-1525862), Diablo Valley College (Award DUE-1525057), Howard University (Award DUE-1524638), the College of Saint Benedict (Award DUE-1525021), Hope College (Award DUE-1524990), and the University of Arkansas, Little Rock (Award DUE-1525037).

This project will expand the content and capabilities of the STEMWiki Hyperlibrary, which was launched to provide vetted Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) learning resources to the public in the form of easily accessible, online college textbooks that alleviate the rising costs of postsecondary education. The STEMWiki Hyperlibrary consists of a number of connected, discipline-focused hypertext applications (ChemWiki, BioWiki, MathWiki, StatWiki, GeoWiki, PhysWiki), which are freely accessible to students regardless of socioeconomic or educational backgrounds. The ChemWiki (http://chemwiki.ucdavis.edu) is currently the most developed STEMWiki, with millions of visits each month. By making high-quality STEM learning resources readily available, the project will positively impact at least four main populations: (1) the non-science community; (2) socioeconomically disadvantaged students; (3) smaller or financially disadvantaged academic institutions, including high schools, that wish to adopt new learning technologies but cannot afford the initial steep costs of a new curriculum; and (4) discipline-based education researchers looking for a platform on which to evaluate new interdisciplinary approaches and curriculum modifications, which would otherwise absorb too large of a budget to develop from scratch. Once sufficiently developed, the Hyperlibary will be a power platform for the dissemination of new educational content and the evaluation of emerging educational technologies.

The STEMWiki Hyperlibrary is designed as a collaboratively constructed learning environment that enables the dissemination and evaluation of new educational resources and approaches as online course textbooks, with an emphasis on data-driven assessment of student learning and performance. The STEMWikis allow learners to cooperatively construct and organize knowledge, providing an important alternative to "one size fits all" instruction in which content is presented in a static, prepackaged manner. In this project, the investigators will augment the constituent STEMWikis of the Hyperlibrary with ancillary homework and simulation applications, as well as formative assessment modules. They will integrate the content of the STEMWikis both horizontally (across multiple STEM fields) and vertically (across multiple levels of complexity) within a network that will provide not just single textbooks but a rich "hyperlibrary" through which new, interconnected STEM textbooks can be constructed. The result will be an easy-to-use platform on which faculty members can collaborate to create and publish reusable, online pedagogical content. The project team will add ancillary online homework (the Student Ability Rating and Inquiry System [SARIS]) and simulations (via the ChemCollective, http://www.chemcollective.org). From these components, they will build an assessment infrastructure that tracks and correlates use of individual Wiki-based textbooks with simulations, homework activity, and exam performance, with the goal of identifying and tracking student performance across multiple STEM curricula.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This final outcomes report represents the $20,000 component of NSF proposal 1525037, Collaborative Research: Developing and Assessing Effective Cyberlearning within the STEMWiki Hyperlibrary, which was awarded to the University of Arkansas ? Little Rock. The primary emphasis of this work dealt with the integration of the ChemCollective Virtual Laboratory developed by David Yaron of Carnegie Mellon University into the STEMWiki HyperLibrary, which has since become LibreText.  The Virtual Laboratory uses thermodynamic equations to calculate equilibrium concentrations of reactants and products based on the actual reagents and concentrations students choose to mix in the lab's graphical user interface. This allows for open ended questions where the students need to design the experiment required to provide the needed information to answer the question. There were technical issues and Yaron's team converted the old Java-based virtual labs into HTML-5 based ones, that could be run in the hyperlibrary. In addition to the default laboratory, eleven custom laboratories were embedded with unique stockrooms of reagents designed for specific problems. These were of two types of virtual labs, interactive practice problems and graded activities where students were given an unknown and required to answer a question. A typical graded activity was like the lab where students determined the Ka and normal weight of an unknown solid acid. As student's did not know what the acid was, they had to choose an initial concentration of base, and then identify what quantity of acid could be neutralized by that base without using more volume than their equipment could hold.  Once they did that, they could go ahead and run a titration.

In addition to integrating Virtual Labs into LibreText a collection of around 175 short single topic videos based on PI Belford's lectures were created and integrated into the LibreText hyperlibrary. The majority of these were demonstrating how to solve problems, and were developed right after lecture with the idea of supporting the lecture, so that the LibreText content would better complement the lecture content. These videos are responsive and work on cell phones. Some of them were integrated into the narrative of the text and visible when you viewed a page, while others were hidden in answers to text exercises that pop up when you click on the "show answer" link.

PI Belford also worked with developers from the hypothes.is web annotation system (https://web.hypothes.is/) to embed their service into LibreText, and pilot its use with General Chemistry students at UALR. Hypothes.is allowed students to highlight text and make comments in an accordion style overlay that could be private, shared with their class or made public.  If the professor replied to a class annotation the student would get an email with the reply, and the entire class could activate the overlay and read the annotation based discussions. If students clicked on one of the annotations in the overlay while reviewing them, the page would scroll to the text that was highlighted, and thus every student could see the discussion in the context of the text. If students tagged an annotation on any open access page on the web with the tag that was assigned to each chapter's table of contents, that annotation would appear at the bottom of that chapter's table of contents, even if the page was not part of LibreText.  This allowed students to ask questions on PDF problem sets and interactive JavaScript quizzes that were posted online, which would then be aggregated on the chapter's table of contents where the instructor could easily review them.  Each aggregated annotation had a contextual link that when activated would open the annotated page the student had tagged in a new browser window, scroll down to the highlighted text and show the annotation in the overlay. This allowed the instructor to easily navigate student questions across multiple web pages, and thus extend the narrative of the chapter to any open access text-based content on the web.
